name: lycopodium-clavatum
country-or-region-of-origin: Alaska, Canada, south to Georgia and west to California.
light: Deep shade (Less than 2 hours to no direct sunlight)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Spores cones are 2-6 inches tall and yellow-green. They display from July to September.
flower-description: No flowers. The plant reproduces by spores.
leaf-description: Spreading, ascending needle or scale-like leaves on the distal third of the branches.
stem-description: Horizontal stems on substrate surface with clusters of upright shoots and a dominant main shoot with 3 to 6 branches mostly in lower half of the plant.
uses: Spores have been used as a powder for infants and to protect raw skin. It has been used to treat unspecified medicinal disorders, as animal food, an ornamental plant and a medicine.
